item.title: China’s Huawei has big ambitions to weaken the US grip on AI leadership
item.description: In spite of tensions with the US and its allies, Huawei is rapidly building a suite of AI offerings unmatched by any other company on the planet.

item.title: A simple blood test to predict premature births could save babies’ lives
item.description: Complications from preterm birth are the leading cause of death worldwide in children under five.

item.title: Bill Gates explains why we should all be optimists
item.description:
We sat down to talk about breakthrough technologies, China, 
and reasons to be cheerful with this issue’s guest editor.

item.title: 10 Breakthrough Technologies 2019, curated by Bill Gates
item.description: We asked Gates to choose this year’s list of inventions that will change the world for the better.

item.title: Why AI is a threat to democracy—and what we can do to stop it
item.description: Futurist and NYU professor Amy Webb on an impending artificial intelligence catastrophe—and why there’s still hope it can be averted.

item.title: China’s CRISPR twins might have had their brains inadvertently enhanced
item.description: New research suggests that a controversial gene-editing experiment to make children resistant to HIV may also have enhanced their ability to learn and form memories.

item.title: The first privately funded trip to the moon is about to launch
item.description: After failing to claim the Lunar X Prize (which, to be fair, everyone did), the Israeli firm SpaceIL could have a rover on lunar soil in a little over a month.

item.title: The technology behind OpenAI’s fiction-writing, fake-news-spewing AI, explained
item.description: The language model can write like a human, but it doesn’t have a clue what it’s saying.

item.title: AI is reinventing the way we invent
item.description: The biggest impact of artificial intelligence will be to help humans make discoveries we couldn’t make on our own.

item.title: Never mind killer robots—here are six real AI dangers to watch out for in 2019
item.description: Last year a string of controversies revealed a darker (and dumber) side to artificial intelligence.

item.title: The Reunion: a new science-fiction story about surveillance in China
item.description: Technology is making people unhinged and violent. Can an algorithm stop them?

item.title: Seven New Year’s resolutions for Big Tech in 2019
item.description: 2018 was a no good, very bad year for Silicon Valley. Here’s some of the things tech giants should commit to do next year to avoid a repeat performance.

item.title: The day I tasted climate change
item.description: Every one of us will have a moment when global warming gets personal.

item.title: All the reasons 2018 was a breakout year for DNA data
item.description: Gene information on millions of people is revolutionizing how we predict disease, catch criminals, and find new drugs.

item.title: How Google took on China—and lost
item.description: It used to be that while Google wanted China, China really needed Google. Not any more.

item.title: The biggest technology failures of 2018
item.description: From gene-edited babies to guaranteed-fatal brain uploads, it was a bumper year for technology misfires and misuses.

item.title: Cryptocurrencies crashed in 2018. Now they’re right where they should be.
item.description: A year ago, Bitcoin and its brethren were headed to the moon. These days they’re much more grounded.

item.title: The biggest technology failures of 2018
item.description: From gene-edited babies to guaranteed-fatal brain uploads, it was a bumper year for technology misfires and misuses.

item.title: Science vs. the state: a family saga at the Caltech of China
item.description: Three generations of personal and political history show the tensions between the Communist Party’s need for knowledge and its need for ideological control.

item.title: China vs. the US: Who wins and who loses
item.description: An interview with Yasheng Huang, MIT professor and expert on entrepreneurship in China.
